title: A Matter of Time
descriptions:
“A Matter of Time” (1976) is a wistful, baroque character study set in Rome, following the self-discovery of a young hotel maid who becomes muse, confidante, and protégé to a once-glamorous aristocrat living on memories. Nina, an inexperienced but curious working-class girl, begins a job at an opulent old hotel, where she’s assigned to the suite of the Contessa Sanziani, an eccentric, aging noblewoman whose life once glittered with privilege, art, and romance. The Contessa senses in Nina a spark of imagination and ambition and draws her into a world of recollections and reveries that blur the line between reality and performance.

Through stories that feel like theatrical vignettes, the Contessa recounts encounters with artists, lovers, and royalty, painting herself as a woman who lived for beauty and sensation. She coaches Nina in elegance, poise, and the power of reinvention, urging her to see beyond her circumstances. The Contessa’s suite becomes a stage where costumes are tried on, identities improvised, and lessons in allure and self-possession are enacted. Nina becomes a willing audience and student, absorbing not only the Contessa’s lore but also her philosophy that life is a role one chooses to play—and that time, though cruel, can be cheated through style and memory.

As Nina grows bolder, the film follows her wanderings through Rome’s streets and salons, capturing a city that is both ancient and decadent. She meets figures who mirror the Contessa’s past: an enigmatic artist-photographer, jaded aristocrats, theatrical impresarios, and men who project fantasies onto her. Each encounter nudges Nina further from her background and closer to a persona fashioned from the Contessa’s fables. The hotel’s staff and Nina’s family look on with concern or confusion, sensing that she is drifting into a dream spun by a woman whose best days are behind her.

The Contessa, meanwhile, clings to her legends, performing herself as much as she narrates. Her grandeur is real and counterfeit at once—she may embellish, but her tales carry the weight of a lifetime of desire and disappointment. She pushes Nina to seize every chance, to make admirers and opportunities out of thin air, to understand that society often rewards those who appear to belong. Their bond is tender, manipulative, and mutually sustaining: the Contessa needs a receptive listener and an heir to her illusions; Nina needs a model for escape.

In the film’s middle passages, Nina experiments with her newfound confidence. She adopts gowns, alters her hair, and learns to enter rooms as if they were already hers. She is photographed, courted, and intermittently exploited. Yet each misstep advances her transformation, which is less a corruption than an awakening to the malleability of identity. The Contessa’s health and fortunes ebb, and her suite becomes a fading theater, but she insists on curtain calls to the end—exits should be as artful as entrances.

Eventually, Nina moves beyond the hotel, poised to step into the entertainment world, perhaps cinema itself. When she returns to the Contessa, the old woman’s illusions and reality finally converge: a last audience, a last lesson, and a tacit passing of the torch. The film does not judge whether the Contessa’s life was truth or artifice; it proposes that her artistry created its own truth, and that Nina’s path, forged from borrowed myths, may become her own authentic story.

A melancholic coda frames Nina as a poised figure in her own right, her image echoing the Contessa’s once-iconic silhouette. She is no longer the naïf who entered the hotel; she has learned to navigate a world where time consumes beauty but also bequeaths it, transmuted, to those who watch, remember, and perform. The title’s promise is fulfilled: it is only a matter of time before every muse becomes the star, every audience the performer, and every memory a script for the next life to play.
